reviewText:
I own this for the PSP Vita and PC, i have well over 1k+ hours dumped into the game over the years, It's an extremely replayable top-down rpg with the combat system being very akin to the 2d Zelda games, You compose your party from characters you create in the tavern, you can make them look however you want with the in game editor that is easy to use but very detailed, this editor is also available to make your own gear skins to apply to items gathered while slaying monsters or looting chest. There are Many jobs to choose from, base jobs as well as a few unlockable ones.
You're allowed to Reclass after you reach a certain point in the game, when you choose another job
you retain all abilities/magic, ''Magic circles'' and a fraction of your stats, There are 3 dungeon modes.
Story mode, Ran-Geon ''Random dungeon'' and Tri-Geon ''Triple Dungeons''  (Ran/Tri are both randomised Multi Floored dungeons) Really basic summation of the game, It's worth its ''Steep'' price in my opinion IF you have the option to get it on the PSP/VITA over PC do so, But if PC is your only platform then it's no big deal, it's just as responsive as the handhelds and emulated great as well. Thank you for taking your time to read the review, and good luck!
voteText: 46 of 51 people (90%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Before thinking I completely recommend this game, hold on for a second and read ahead.

TLDR: Please play the game... But not on Steam

ClaDun x2 IS a fun game. It's exciting to play, has good music and the customization options are through the roof.
Under any normal circumstance, I would recommend this game, but not in this scenario.

20 US dollars is not what this game is worth to any normal player. I would recommend this game on a sale, but there's one problem with that; The publisher has abandoned Steam. There is most likely never going to be a sale for this game ever again and that's the sad part. I want to tell my friends to buy it. I WANT to let others have this on their library, but 20 dollars is WAY too much, especially considering that it's not very well ported. There's flickering with the Steam Overlay and is generally a pain, but I had loads of fun.

I cannot recommend this game for 20 dollars.
I recommend getting the PSP version, whether it's emulated or not is not my choice.

reviewText:
RPG with zelda combat and oodles of customization. The game is easy to learn, difficult to master with some pretty complex character customization. And of course it has the trademark NIS grind.

Overall a pretty enjoyable game, though the port kind of sucks. It's at the native resolution (it's a psp game so yeah...) has some issues in controller configuration (it took me half an hour to figure why buttons weren't binding...), and is locked at 30fps.

If you don't mind the graphics it'll be fun until it gets repetitve. Your mileage will vary on that; the regular dungeons mix things up pretty well, but if you do the randomly generated dungeons they seem to be quite similar most of the time and get old. Nothing like Disgaea's item world at all.

reviewText:
JRPG lover? You want ACTION-Based RPG and not turn-based? Want the pixels? Love to grind? Don't care about the story? Want to customize your charater's appearance from top to bottom? Even if the story is lackluster and if you're in doubt if this game works, just give the demo a shot.

A brief warning. This game is a PSP port and its' multiplayer features is not implemented fully at the moment because the PSP port's multiplayer works in ad-hoc mode (via playing locally). However, if you want a good JRPG game while your internet is screwed over, pick this game up immediately. People outside the JRPG realm?... Hard to say. There is a tutorial on it, but this game will not hold your hand once you get out of Trial Island which is more than enough for me.

This game can easily fill in 20-40~ hours of gameplay AT THE LEAST. It can go more when you want to reach cap on 8~10 different characters (Level 99 is the cap)

Oh, and not to forget to mention there's a Job Changer, so you can do the same grind, AGAIN! And max initial cap of any stat is 999. The universal cap is 9999. So I still got a longggggggggg way to go.

The learning curve is steep when the Magic Circle" system is into play. Basically
date: you can stack your sub-characters together with your main character (the one you physically play with)
recommended: and the stats get transferred to your Main Character while special tiles like "Growth" will determine your Sub Character's Leveling Parameters.\n\nIf this looks like rocket science to you
hoursPlayed: this may not be the game to pass up and if you want a simpler game
voteText: I will forward you to Binding of Isaac or Hack
votesTotal: and not on Steam). For a roguelike with a slightly higher learning curve
votesFunny: I recommend Dungeons of Dreadmor.\n\nIn addition
commentsCount:
I have a 4 1/2 hour stream of a first game impression by me if you want to check that out: http://www.twitch.tv/critical__hit/b/328931483

JRPG Fans wanting a grind? Insta-buy.
Everyone else? Wait for a big sale."

reviewText:
Don't let the playtime fool you- the mojority of time I spent playing this game was in offline mode, so about 100~ hours are missing there.

Cladun X2 is a game made for those who love customization.  Want to smack enemies with a giant wooden spoon?  Go for it.  Want to play as one of your favorite RPG characters?  If you can sprite art it, sure.  Add along the fact that levels and dungeons go to an obscenely high number (same guys who made Disgaea, of course this is going to happen,) this is not a game you will get bored of quickly.

it does have one major flaw though- this is a PSP port, and the wonky controls show that immediately.  You would think that a game that prides itself on customization would allow you to change the controls.

Another flaw is this does NOT allow you to transfer any of your art or data from the PSP game itself, so if you're buying this a second time you will be starting over from scratch.

All in all, if you can get past the odd controls and you're a sucker for replay/customization, this is the game for you.

reviewText:
An extremely fun little action rpg with good combat, and robust customization that allows you to not only edit your characters stats and abilities in depth, but even their appearance pixel by pixel.

Control and combat wise, it's a top down action rpg, similar to Legend of Zelda visually and control wise. You can jump, you can block, you can slide, and you got a variety of abilities and weapon types at your disposal. There's even a decent amount of finesse and tricks you can do, like cancelling sword slashes into blockings and then jumping out of danger to save yourself, or buffering jumps into short jumping attacks.

The enemies you face also have nice variety, and do a good job of remaining fairly unpredictable even after you've learned their fighting styles. Another thing I especially love, is that the game incorporates a subtle stealth element. Enemies won't start chasing and attacking you till they spot you, but once they do they'll chase you through the entire dungeon. Attempting to run from an enemy will cause you to rush by other enemies, who will also break into chase. This results in a frantic chase through the entire dungeon as you attempt to escape in time from the horde trying to corner you.

For customization, you're allowed to create as many characters as you like, selecting jobs, weapons, and abilities. You strengthen their abilities and growth in certain areas by drawing on the strength of other characters you've created. Visually, you can edit weapons and characters (and even animation) of your characters pixel by pixel. Don't be daunted though, because the game uses a great template for creating fairly basic but still cute looking sprites. More artistic players can still create some great stuff though.

The actual gameplay is basically divided into two games. You can make your way through the static progression of dungeons of the main campaign, which has decent level/dungeon design and is balanced well enough to not require any grinding. Alternatively, you can take on a massive 100 floor randomly generated dungeon, which feels more like a rogue like.

I personally love the randomly generated dungeon, the way stealth, combat, traps, and preparation are balanced is fantastic. Unfortunately, enemies increase in level ridiculously fast as you proceed through the floors. Eventually your attacks will do 0 damage, so it's really quite impossible to clear the dungeon based on skill alone. While making it as far as you can and escaping with random rare loot (you lose everything if you die before making it to an exit), is plenty exciting and skillbased, it's still ultimately a long term process to clear it the entire dungeon itself.

ClaDun X2 is still a fantastic game, plenty fun, and allows you to play and create your characters to suit your needs. I would highly recommend it for some hack and slash fun.

Japan yet again confirms it cannot into keyboards so grab a controller.
NiS is at it again with its over-the-top RPG systems which may be a turnoff (constant need to switch characters between Main Character (the one you play as through the dungeon) and Sub Character (the one that supports MC from behind the screen giving buffs and stats) states in order not to screw up their stats.

reviewText:
THIS GAME WILL EAT YOUR SOUL!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! in a good way :D
And by that, I mean it's an AMAZING RPG game!
It not only has randomly generated dungeons, it also has ingame editors which allow you to make your own sprites for weapons, armors, characters and their animations, and also has a music editor so you can make your own music!
Personally I LOVE the retro feel it has to it and how it feels somewhat like a super nintendo game. Did I mention randomly generated dungeons? Oh yea and there are two dungeon systems which the goal is to reach floor 99 with many twists and turns along the way to keep you entertained (watch out for Doom Gates, (you'll know what I mean when you find one))

This game is a perfect PC ARPG game you can enjoy and is comparable to iOS/Android titles like Zenonia, Tales of Inotia, and Seed (at least in my opinion).

reviewText: Cladun X2 is a real time action dungeon crawler graced by the affinity for the infinite as it was made by legendary Nippon Ichi Software (the folks who did Disgaea). Not only is the action well designed for its genre but it is also complemented by the depth of the magic circle system and alternating main character gameplay. Included with the game is a MML Music Editor and Sprite designer so you can create your own characters, weapons, armor and music to be used in game. I can definitely recommend this one without any regrets, but it is a grind and is tough.

reviewText: A mediocre dungeon crawler, but i'm OCD about the level of editbale items and characters
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OCoF0DRM2LI

Cladun X2 is about grinding and I mean serious grinding. The game is set in the tiny World of Arcanus Cella, where you basically have to fight in endless dungeons. You’ll come across other characters who are trapped in this World with you. The game features a lot of customisation for your characters. For my character the ‘comiccon’ I chose warrior class, then you have to choose a job skill and a personality trait. I picked narcissism as the trait, it doesn’t really have an effect on the gameplay, it’s just for laughs to be honest. You can create a new character at any time by going to the main menu, you can have as many characters as you want but you can only have 4 in your party at any one time.

You might be surprised that some of the dungeons in the game can be beaten in less than 30 seconds, this is actually a big plus for the game. The usual formula goes a little something like this; you beat a handful of dungeons get some items and gold. You can choose from two handed weapons like the axe, or go for the staff, sword and shield, or dagger. The staff has elemental based attacks like fire, and water, which reminds me of something like poke’mon.

The key mechanic in the game is magic circles, they basically allow you to buff your party any way your want, by placing artefacts on the corresponding spots in the circle you can give your party effect bonus such as HP+1, Attack+1, Defense+1, along with some more complicated effects. There are many different magic circles that allow for thousands of artefact combinations and therefore a practically unlimited number of different buffs.

Add into this that dropped weapons, and items have a rare title rate, meaning they also can have buffs and elemental bonuses. If you thought you weren’t going to get enough grinding in this game, well you’re wrong because add into this you have two special kinds of dungeon called neogeons and trigeons. Neogeons are randomly generated 99 floor dungeons, filled with traps and high level demons on each floor, a trigeon is the same just 3 times as large basically. In these dungeons you will come across angel and devil gates at the end of every floor these will randomly change the rare title drop rate, additionally an angel gate can change to a devil gate once you go through it and vice versa. In other words these dungeons are completely random so any skill you thought you had will be put to the test in the extreme.

Beating these uber-hard dungeons, giving you’re party super-rare gear, and configuring magic circles is what this game is about. Yes there is a story..technically. But it’s mostly early on in random cutscenes that are mostly about humour more than anything else. Although this game was not developed by Nippon Icchi Software only published by them it definitely does feel like something they would have made, quirky, and for the hardcore fans of role playing games who have gotten bored of Final Fantasy and the traditional mainstream titles.

The visuals as you can see are beautiful, they are like a 16 bit classic with hyper detailed animations, the attack patterns in this game are very fluid and the soundtrack is top notch perfect for old school adventuring. You even have the option to set it to classic BGM’s to give you the authentic retro feel. Although I wouldn’t personally.

Cladun X2 is even more obscure than it’s prequel; Cladun: This is an Rpg! So chances are many people didn’t buy the game on PSN, or play it on the PSP, or even when it was re-released on steam. It wasn’t promoted terribly well and system prisma doesn’t have the same weight as Square Enix so the series kind of disappeared into obscurity before the PlayStation Vita or PS4 came out. Which is a shame. This game is still worth playing if you have enjoyed previous Nippon Icchi Software titles, enjoy a challenge, and above all absolutely love grinding, as in Disgaea 4: A Promise Revisited levels of grinding.

reviewText:
I loved this game the with its customization and old school feel it is amazing. I recommend this game to anyone who loves creating there own characters and weapons.

Positives+
+Fun gameplay
+Classic Classes
+Create your own character
+Create silly weapons
+Boss battles

Negatives-
-repetitive dungeons
-storymode is not very detailed
-no multiplayer :(

reviewText: Create a group and play through a story or randomly generated dungeons. Interesting party system where your party members support you with increased stats or abilities while you only have to play as one character. You can level your characters and class change them anytime to create the team you want. Lots of different items to allow you to customise your character even more. The combat is quick and easy to learn allowing you to jump right in and have fun.
